The Act may be cited as the "Holocaust Insurance Accountability Act of 2016" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The "Holocaust Insurance Accountability Act of 2016" aims to enforce State laws on disclosing information about Holocaust-era insurance policies, despite previous legal challenges. It seeks to help US citizens and beneficiaries of these policies understand their rights. The "Holocaust Insurance Accountability Act of 2016" allows US citizens to sue in US courts to recover proceeds from Holocaust-era insurance policies, regardless of preemptive foreign policy defenses. It also prevents defenses based on prior judgments or settlements that wrongly concluded State law claims were preempted by foreign policy. The "Holocaust Insurance Accountability Act of 2016" aims to allow US citizens to sue for Holocaust-era insurance policies in US courts, with a uniform statute of limitations of 10 years. It also seeks to preserve Congress's lawmaking powers under the Constitution, despite conflicting judicial decisions. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, a "beneficiary" includes a named insured, named beneficiary, heir, assignee, or legal representative under a covered policy. A "covered policy" refers to any insurance policy in effect between January 31, 1933, and December 31, 1945, issued to a policyholder domiciled in areas occupied by Nazi Germany or Switzerland. The term "insurer" refers to any person engaged in the business of insurance, including reinsurance, who issued a covered policy. It also includes any successor in interest to the insurer. The term "Nazi Germany" encompasses the Nazi government of Germany and any government that had friendly relations with, was allied with, or controlled by the Nazi government, or claimed sovereignty over areas occupied by Nazi military forces. The term "related company" refers to an affiliate as defined in the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act. SEC. 4. PRIVATE RIGHT OF ACTION; CIVIL ACTIONS. A beneficiary of a covered policy can sue the insurer or related company to recover policy proceeds. Process serving for a civil action can be nationwide. The court must award the beneficiary the proceeds due under the policy in a successful civil action. In a successful civil action, a beneficiary of a covered policy can recover policy proceeds, prejudgment interest at 6 percent per year, and any necessary relief. If bad faith is found, treble damages may be awarded. Additionally, reasonable attorney's fees and costs must be awarded to the prevailing party. The prevailing beneficiary in a civil action under this section may receive reasonable attorney's fees and costs. A civil action cannot be brought under this section 10 years after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. EFFECT OF PRIOR JUDGMENTS AND RELEASES. Effect of Prior Judgments and Releases: A judgment or release will not prevent any claim under section 4, regardless of when it was entered or agreed upon. EFFECT ON STATE LAWS. This Act does not supersede or preempt any State law unless in conflict with this Act.

SEC. 8. TIMELINESS OF ACTIONS UNDER STATE LAW. Claims under State laws described in section 6(a) are not considered untimely based on statutes of limitations if filed within 10 years of this Act's enactment.

SEC. 9. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act remains unaffected.

SEC. 10. EFFECTIVE DATE; APPLICABILITY. The Act will take effect on the date of enactment and will apply to any claim related to a covered policy brought before, on, or after the enactment date.
